title: I have changes in both `main` and `test` on my local git repository. I wish t...

parts: I have changes in both `main` and `test` on my local git repository. I wish to discard changes made to `test` and instead update it with those made to `main`. What should I do?

If you want **`test` to become exactly the same as `main`** (and you don’t care about keeping anything currently on `test`), do a hard reset of `test` to `main`.

### 1) Make sure the changes you want from `main` are saved
On `main`, either **commit** the changes (recommended) or you won’t have a stable “thing” to copy to `test`.

```bash
git switch main
git status
git add -A
git commit -m "Your message"
```

*(If `main` is already committed / up to date, skip this.)*

### 2) Discard `test`’s local changes and make it match `main`
```bash
git switch test
git reset --hard main
git clean -fd   # optional: removes untracked files/dirs too
```

After this, `test` points at the same commit as `main`, and the working tree matches it.

### 3) If `test` exists on a remote and you need the remote updated
This rewrites the remote `test` branch to match your local `test`:

```bash
git push --force-with-lease origin test
```

---

#### Notes / safety
- `git reset --hard` **permanently discards** uncommitted work on `test`.
- If what you actually meant was “keep `test`’s commits but incorporate `main`”, you’d use `git merge main` (or rebase) instead—say so and I’ll tailor the exact commands.
i now wish to continue working on `test`

If you already ran the reset, then **`test` is now identical to `main`**. To continue working, just stay on `test` and commit new work there.

```bash
git switch test
git status
# edit files...
git add -A
git commit -m "Work on test"
```

If you want your `test` branch on the remote to reflect this (and then your new commits):

```bash
git push -u origin test
```

Later, if `main` moves forward and you want to bring those updates into `test` while keeping your `test`-only commits, do either:

```bash
git switch test
git merge main
# or: git rebase main
```
